title: 113_hr3428
content: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section, 41A, which provides a credit for increasing development activities. The new section 41A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers to elect a development credit equal to 30% of qualified development expenses exceeding 50% of the average expenses from the previous 3 years. Qualified development expenses include in-house and contract development expenses paid or incurred during the taxable year. The terms 'in-house development expenses' and 'contract development expenses' are defined in relation to 'qualified development' for tax purposes. Qualified development involves applying knowledge towards creating useful material, devices, or systems. Rules from section 41(d)(1) apply to development expenses. The tax credit under this section applies if there are no qualified development expenses in any of the 3 preceding years. The credit rate is 12 percent of the qualified development expenses for the taxable year. An election made under this section applies to the current taxable year and all future years unless revoked with the Secretary's consent. Other special rules similar to section 41 apply to this section. The tax credit under this section applies if there are no qualified development expenses in any of the 3 preceding years. The credit rate is 12 percent of the qualified development expenses for the taxable year. An election made under this section applies to the current taxable year and all future years unless revoked with the Secretary's consent. Other special rules similar to section 41 apply to this section. Subsections (d)(4), (f), and (g) of section 41 shall apply for purposes of this section. This section shall not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2018. Coordination with Section 41 includes that in the case of any taxable year for which an election is in effect under section 41A, qualified research expenses shall not include any qualified development expenses. Coordination with deductions includes a credit for increasing development activities. No deduction allowed for portion of qualified development expenses equal to credit determined under section 41A(a). If credit exceeds deduction, reduce capital account expenses by the excess amount. The excess amount of the credit under section 41A(a) for a taxable year can be reduced from capital account expenses. An election for a reduced credit can be made, resulting in a different calculation for the credit amount. The excess credit under section 41A(a) for a taxable year can be reduced from capital account expenses by making an election for a reduced credit, which results in a different calculation for the credit amount. An election under this paragraph must be made by the time for filing the tax return for the year and is irrevocable once made. Controlled groups are subject to the rules of subsection (b) for this purpose. Subsection (b) of section 38 pertains to the General Business Credit. The General Business Credit under section 38 of the tax code is amended to include a new development credit determined under section 41A. These amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2013. SEC. 2. The alternative simplified credit for research is increased to 20 percent, up from 14 percent. A special rule raises the credit to 8 percent in case of no qualified research expenses in the previous 3 years. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2013. Extension of the research activities credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is extended from December 31, 2013, to December 31, 2018. This amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2013.
